results.statement: The Role of Urinary Catheters. For decades, urinary catheters facilitate bladder drainage and enable precise urine output monitoring in acutely ill or post-operative patients.
results.matched_evidence: - 1. Feneley 2015.pdf: The eponymous indwelling balloon-retained catheter (Figure 4) now in worldwide use was conceived by the American urologist Frederic Foley nearly 80 years ago to provide continuous urinary drainage and to control bleeding while haemostasis occurs, following transurethral prostatectomy [14].

results.statement: The Role of Urinary Catheters. Generally, about 25% of hospitalized individuals receive an indwelling urinary catheter.
results.reference: Amit R. Porwal, U.T. Mane, Amit C. Botre, Rahul S. Patil and A.T. Pardesi. Urinary Tract Infection in Indoor Patients with Indwelling Foley’s Catheterisation.
results.matched_evidence: - 3. Amit R, 2016.pdf: The 25% of hospitalized patients undergo urinary catheterisation and the incidence of infection is approximately 5-7% for each day of catheterisation.

results.statement: Burden of CAUTI. Each additional day of catheterization increases bacteriuria risk by 3-7%
results.reference: Sharma RK, Parihar SS, Kinimi SV, Choudhary S. An Observational Study from Northern India to Evaluate Catheter-associated Urinary Tract Infection in Medical Intensive Care Unit at a Tertiary Care Centre. Indian Journal of Critical Care Medicine. 2023;27(9):642-646.
results.matched_evidence: - 6. Sharma RK 2023.pdf: The duration of catheterization is the most important factor in the development of bacteriuria, as its daily usage increases the risk of infection by 3-7%.

results.statement: Impact of CAUTI. CAUTI increases the morbidity and mortality by 2.8-fold and length of hospitalization by 1-3 days. – CDC
results.reference: Soundaram GV, Sundaramurthy R, Jeyashree K, Ganesan V, Arunagiri R, Charles J. Impact of Care Bundle Implementation on Incidence of Catheter-associated Urinary Tract Infection: A Comparative Study in the Intensive Care Units of a Tertiary Care Teaching Hospital in South India. Indian Journal of Critical Care Medicine : Peer-reviewed, Official Publication of Indian Society of Critical Care Medicine. 2020;24(7):544-550.
results.matched_evidence: - 7. Soundaram, 2020.pdf: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), CAUTI increases the morbidity and mortality by 2.8-fold and length of hospitalization by 1-3 days.

results.statement: Impact of CAUTI. 3x higher mortality rates in ICU
results.reference: Yu KC, Jung M, Ai C. Characteristics, costs, and outcomes associated with central-line–associated bloodstream infection and hospital-onset bacteremia and fungemia in US hospitals. Infection Control & Hospital Epidemiology. 2023;44(12):1920-1926.

results.statement: Impact of CAUTI. The attributable cost per patient for CAUTI ranged from USD 862 to 1007
results.reference: Chuang LRL, et al. Hospital-wide surveillance of catheter-associated urinary tract infection rates in a Singapore general hospital. Crit Care Shock. 2018;21(2):xx-xx. doi:10.1016/j.pcad.2017.08.031. Accessed November 25, 2025.
results.matched_evidence: - 5. Chaung.pdf: The burden of healthcare-associated infections (HAls) on patient morbidity and mortality is well recognised. CAUTIs are the commonest HAI, with an estimated attributable cost of USD 862-1,007 per patient (2007 value, adjusted for consumer price index).

results.statement: Impact of CAUTI. National IPC guidelines for long-term care facilities and community hospitals highlight CAUTI as a priority healthcare-associated infection and advocate for evidence-based prevention protocols, including the use of silver-coated catheters.

results.statement: Contribution of CAUTI to AMR. 88% of CAUTI isolates are multidrug-resistant
results.reference: Purandare B, Jha T, Khaparde M, Parkhe TS, Lavate R. Incidence Risk Factors and Drug Resistance Patterns of Bacterial Isolates in Patients with Catheter-associated Urinary Tract Infections. Indian Journal of Critical Care Medicine. 2025;29(4):338-344.
results.matched_evidence: - 12. Jha, 2025.pdf: Multidrug resistance was detected in 37 (88.1%) of the 82 isolates.

results.statement: Contribution of CAUTI to AMR. >90% resistance for key antibiotics
results.reference: Purandare B, Jha T, Khaparde M, Parkhe TS, Lavate R. Incidence Risk Factors and Drug Resistance Patterns of Bacterial Isolates in Patients with Catheter-associated Urinary Tract Infections. Indian Journal of Critical Care Medicine. 2025;29(4):338-344.
results.matched_evidence: - 12. Jha, 2025.pdf: Resistance among urinary isolates was 94% for cefoperazone-sulbactam, 90% for ampicillin, 80% for cefepime, 86.44% for amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, 84% for aztreonam, 64.40% for cefuroxime, 64% for piperacillin-tazobactam, ceftriaxone, and ceftazidime, 62.71% for cefotaxime, and 61.01 for trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole regardless of the bacterial species.

results.statement: Catheter Encrustation. Biofilm formation during long-term urethral catheterization increases the risk of catheter encrustation, leading to pain and discomfort for the patient.
results.reference: Liu X, Kamperman M. Smart bacteria-responsive coatings for combating catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Materials Today Bio. 2025;34:102191.14. Chung PH, Wong CW, Lai CK, et al. A prospective interventional study to examine the effect of a silver alloy and hydrogel--coated catheter on the incidence of catheter-associated urinary tract infection. Hong Kong Medical Journal. Published online February 17, 2017.
results.matched_evidence: - 13. Liu, 2025.pdf: Biofilm formation during long-term catheterization and catheter encrustation are the two main problems that make it challenging to treat CAUTIs.

results.statement: Evidence-Based Clinical Performance. reduction in CAUTI incidence compared to standard latex catheters.
results.matched_evidence:
- 14. Chung, 2017.pdf: The incidences of catheter-associated
urinary tract infection per 1000 catheter-days were
6.4 and 9.4, respectively (P=0.095). There was a 31%
reduction in the incidence of catheter-associated
urinary tract infection per 1000 catheter-days in the
silver-coated group.
- 15. Kai Larsen, 2021.pdf: The incidence of symptomatic CAUTI was reduced by 69% in the BIP Foley Catheter group compared to the control group (6.5 vs 20.8 CAUTI/1000 catheter days), with an incidence rate ratio of 0.31 (95% confidence interval: 0.21–0.46; p < 0.001).

results.statement: Prolonged dwell time enables less frequent catheter changes. Bardex™™™ I.C. Foley catheters offer a dwell time of up to 28 days.
results.matched_evidence: - 18. Bardex IC IFU.pdf: Recommended indwelling time not to exceed 28 days.

results.statement: Prolonged dwell time enables less frequent catheter changes. Silver-coated catheters are retained longer without complications compared to conventional catheters.
results.matched_evidence: - 14. Chung, 2017.pdf: The mean catheterisation time per person was the longest in patients using a silver-coated catheter (17.0 days) compared with those using a conventional (10.8 days) or both types of catheter (13.6 days) [P=0.01].

results.statement: Enhanced comfort and superior patient satisfaction. Hydrogel-coated surface maintained a friction coefficient <0.025, remaining <0.050 even after 30 days of simulated use.
results.reference: Gao S, Zeng W, Liu Z, et al. Dual-Function Hydrogel Coating on Silicone Urinary Catheters with Durable Antibacterial Property and Lubricity. Gels. 2025;11(2):128-128.
results.matched_evidence:
- 19. Gao, 2025.pdf: After performing as many as 60 tests, the friction coefficient of silicone urinary catheters coated with DF-1 remained below 0.025, demonstrating the excellent adhesion and lubricity of the hydrogel coatings.
To further verify the durability and lubricity of the coating, we soaked the DF-1 hydrogel coating-coated silicone urinary catheters (named DF-1-S) in artificial urine at 37 °C for 30 days to simulate their in vivo use, and then tested the friction coefficient.

results.statement:
Organization. Urological Association of Asia & Asian Association of Urinary Tract Infection & STIs
2021, Asia
Recommends hydrophilic-coated or antibiotic/silver alloy coated catheters to reduce CAUTI and asymptomatic bacteriuria, especially in settings with high resistance burden.
results.matched_evidence:
- 22. Urological Association of Asia Guidelines.pdf: Evidence for antibiotic or antiseptic impregnated or coated urinary
catheters are as follows [22,40-43]:
• Use of hydrophilic-coated catheters was associated with a lower
incidence of CAUTIs [41,42,44].
• Antibiotic-impregnated catheters lowered rates of asymptomatic
bacteriuria in the short term (less than 1 week), but this effect was
not significant at longer durations [22,40,43,45,46].
• Silver alloy catheters significantly reduced incidence of
asymptomatic bacteriuria, and may be considered.

results.statement:
Organization. International Society for Infectious Diseases (ISID)
2018, Global
Recommends the use of silver alloy hydrogel-coated (SAH) Foley catheters as an effective measure to reduce CAUTI.
results.reference: Rosenthal V, Memish Z, Nicastri E, Leone S, Bearman G. GUIDE to INFECTION CONTROL in the HEALTHCARE SETTING Recommendations for the Prevention of Catheter-Associated Urinary Tract Infections Chapter Editor Topic Outline. https://isid.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/ISID_GUIDE_ CHAPTER_CAUTI.pdf

(2024) examined the efficacy of a silver alloy hydrogel-coated (SAH) catheter +in preventing CAUTI among 132 critically ill ICU patients.

results.statement:
Organization. HPSC Ireland (Health Protection Surveillance Centre)
2011, Ireland
Suggests considering antiseptic or antimicrobial-coated catheters if local CAUTI rates persist despite implementation of multiple prevention strategies.
results.reference: Guidelines for the Prevention of Catheterassociated Urinary Tract Infection Published on behalf of SARI by HSE Health Protection Surveillance Centre 2011. Accessed on https://www.hpsc.ie/a-z /microbiologyantimicrobialresistance/infectioncontrolandhai/guidelines/File,12913,en.pdf
results.matched_evidence: - 24. HPSC Ireland guidelines.pdf: Consider the use of antiseptic or antimicrobial-coated catheters if the local CAUTI rate is not decreasing despite implementation of a multi-system approach: including optimisation of aseptic technique, appropriate management of catheters and regular audit and feedback of surveillance data.

results.statement:
Organization. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
2009, United States
If CAUTI rate does not fall after implementing comprehensive prevention strategies, antimicrobial/ antiseptic coated catheters may be considered.
results.reference: Gould C, Umscheid C, Rajender, Agarwal K, Kuntz G, Pegues D. Guideline for Prevention of Catheter-Associated Urinary Tract Infections 2009.; 2019. https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/media/pdfs/Guideline-CAUTI-H.pdf
results.matched_evidence: - 25. CDC Guidelines.pdf: M. If the CAUTI rate is not decreasing after implementing a comprehensive strategy to reduce rates of CAUTI, consider using antimicrobial/antiseptic-impregnated catheters.

results.statement:
Organization. Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA)
2009, United States
For short-term indwelling urethral catheterization, antimicrobial-coated catheters (silver alloy or antibiotic) may be considered to reduce or delay CA-bacteriuria.
results.reference: Hooton TM, Bradley SF, Cardenas DD, et al. Diagnosis, Prevention, and Treatment of Catheter-Associated Urinary Tract Infection in Adults: 2009 International Clinical Practice Guidelines from the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Clinical Infectious Diseases. 2010;50(5):625-663. Abbreviations: CAUTI: Catheter associated urinary tract infections; CDC: Centers for disease control and prevention; ICU: Intensive care unit; INR: Indian rupee; APSIC: Asia Pacific society of infection control; MOH: Ministry of health; AMR: Antimicrobial resistance; IC: Infection control.
results.matched_evidence: - 26. IDSA Guidelines.pdf: In patients with short-term indwelling urethral catheterization, antimicrobial (silver alloy or antibiotic)-coated urinary catheters may be considered to reduce or delay the onset of CA-bacteriuria (B-II).
